STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 27, 2023
Ellen Westgate
Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw
4925 Packard St.
Ann Arbor, MI, 48108-1521
RE: License#: CB810201018
Dear Ms. Westgate:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 12/15/23. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw
Licensee Designee: Ellen Westgate
Chief Administrator: Ellen Westgate
Name of Agency: Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw

Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
Agency Telephone #: (313) 971-9781
Original Issuance Date: 01/01/1992

homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child’s
placement at least once every month.
Two of three foster care files had one monthly foster home visit contact missing.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/19/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 1/17/23
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of three foster care files did not have a current dental as of November 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency, the borrowing agency shall have a
record containing all the following…

One of three borrowed homes did not have the required documents signed prior
to the beginning of the borrowed bed agreement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/19/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 1/17/23
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Two of three adoption home studies were not completed within the required
timeframe.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
One of three foster care files did not have a quarterly updated medical passport
for one quarter.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/19/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 1/17/23
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
• Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• Semi-Annual Transition Meeting- Within 30
calendar days after the child’s 14th birthday and
every six months thereafter.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
One of three foster care files did not have an FTM completed within 30 days prior
to the USP.
One of three foster care files did not have a semi-annual transition plan
completed since June 2022.

Two of three foster care files did not have an 1105 completed after an FTM. This
was true of four FTMs.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/19/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 1/17/23
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Immunizations- When a parent determines they do not wish to have their child
vaccinated, the agency must complete waiver documentation as required by
rule 400.12413 (d).
• Medical Passports- Program Office has advised that Medical Passports must
be updated and saved in MiSACWIS quarterly, for all youth, even if
signatures are not required at the time.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
One CAP, aproved 1/17/23, was the result of the 12/19/22 interim review. The
agency reported implementation of most parts of their CAP. However, due to
some staffing issues, some parts of the CAP were not as successful as
anticipated. During the previous review the agency had eleven violations. During
the current review six violations were found. Three were repeat violations. Overall,
the agency has shown improvement in several areas.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed and discussed. The agency
reported struggling with staffing over this past year. Over the past several months,
there were vacancies in many full-time positions. The agency continues to post
open positions but has had difficulty finding qualified applicants. Staff turnover has
impacted some implementation of the 1/17/23 CAP. The CAP continues to be
reviewed during monthly staff meetings. Supervisors have also increased
monitoring of timeframes which has aided in improved compliance. Although some

adjustments will be made as a result of the current review, some portions of the
prior CAP will remain in place as they have been effective.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were found.
Staff and Interviews
Two staff were interviewed. One staff was a new licensing worker. She reported
being very satisfied working at this agency. Her supervisor is helpful and
encouraging. Staff are supportive and kind. The licensing worker stated she gets
everything she needs there and does not have any concerns or suggestions for
improvement. The second staff was a foster care worker that has been with the
agency less than a year. She reported that her supervisor is knowledgeable and
great at keeping her on track. The worker indicated the agency is engaging and
listens well to staff. She did not have any concerns or suggestions for
improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the 2022 review. The
large office holds several CSSW programs. The foster care area of the building
has adequate space for staff and clients. There is sufficient secure storage for
confidential information.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
12/21/2023
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12/27/2023
Rorie Dodge-Pifer Date
Area Manager
